question.title: Mapping JFormattedTextField text to value on submit only
question.body:
DefaultFormatter invokes the stringToValue() function even if the text value is not (yet) committed, that is on each key type.

If the function is expensive, e.g. involves some IO, it may be suboptimal. For example, in our case, the user may type in an ICD-10 code, press Enter, and the corresponding disease object, if present, will be fetched from the DB and set as the field's value.

Can I avoid it? I want any conversion attempts to take place only once the string is submitted by the user — on Enter. I think we should probably revert on focus loss with setFocusLossBehavior(JFormattedTextField.REVERT).

Perhaps, I shouldn't put the string-to-object mapping logic in the stringToValue() method at all and instead listen to "value" property changes (which reflect only committed changes). I was thinking along the lines of, "Well, if I include the value-to-string mapping in the AbstractFormatter, I should probably put the opposite mapping there as well". In any case, which parts of the API am I supposed to override and how — including the validation logic? I believe we can assume a committed value can be always mapped to a string, but the opposite is not always true. Note valueToString() can throw ParseException which suggests the method can validate. Then it seems unusual Swing encourages validation of all intermediate input.

Java 8.

import javax.swing.JFormattedTextField;
import javax.swing.JFormattedTextField.AbstractFormatter;
import javax.swing.JFormattedTextField.AbstractFormatterFactory;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.WindowConstants;
import javax.swing.text.DefaultFormatter;
import javax.swing.text.DefaultFormatterFactory;
import java.awt.Component;
import java.awt.Container;

public class FormattedTextFieldDemo {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Formatted Text Field Demo");
        frame.setContentPane(createMainPanel());
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        frame.pack();
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    private static Container createMainPanel() {
        JPanel panel = new JPanel();
        panel.add(createTextField());
        return panel;
    }

    private static Component createTextField() {
        JFormattedTextField field = new JFormattedTextField();
        field.setColumns(10);
        field.setFormatterFactory(createFormatterFactory());
        field.addPropertyChangeListener("value", e -> System.out.printf("Value changed. New value: %s\n", e.getNewValue()));
        return field;
    }

    private static AbstractFormatterFactory createFormatterFactory() {
        DefaultFormatterFactory formatterFactory = new DefaultFormatterFactory();
        formatterFactory.setDefaultFormatter(createFormatter());
        return formatterFactory;
    }

    private static AbstractFormatter createFormatter() {
        AbstractFormatter formatter = new DefaultFormatter() {
            @Override
            public Object stringToValue(String string) {
                System.out.println("Performing expensive operation...");
                return (string == null) ? null : new Person(string);
            }
        };
        return formatter;
    }
}

public class Person {

    private String name;

    public Person(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }

    public void setName(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }

    @Override
    public String toString() {
        return "Person " + name;
    }
}

As you type, you may see logs similar to this:

Value changed. New value: null
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...
Performing expensive operation...

answers.body:
I'm not sure what you need, but I understand that basically, you expect a certain event to occur when you press enter, so I took the liberty of creating this little code, hoping it will serve as a basis for you.

public class FormattedTextFieldDemo {

   void start() {

        // it is important to create the user interface on the event thread.
      SwingUtilities.invokeLater( () -> {
         JFrame frame = new JFrame( "Formatted Text Field Demo" );
         frame.setContentPane( createMainPanel() );
         frame.setLocationRelativeTo( null );
         frame.pack();
         frame.setDefaultCloseOperation( WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE );
         frame.setVisible( true ); 
      });
   }

   Container createMainPanel() {
      JPanel panel = new JPanel();
      panel.add( createTextField() );
      return panel;
   }

   Component createTextField() {
      JFormattedTextField field = new JFormattedTextField();
      field.setColumns( 10 );

        // we replaced "addPropertyChangeListener" with "addKeyListener"
      field.addKeyListener( new KeyAdapter() {
         @Override
         public void keyReleased( KeyEvent e ) {

              // modify by "camickr" suggestion
            if( e.getKeyCode() == KeyEvent.VK_ENTER ) {

                 // I'm not sure if you should implement this,
                 // I just gave an example.
               String string = field.getText();
               System.out.println( "Value changed. New value: %s\n" + string );
               System.out.println( "Performing expensive operation..." );
               field.setText( string == null ? null : new Person( string ).toString() ); // sorry, I have a few extra characters left over.
            }
         }
      } );
      return field;
   }

   public static void main( String[] args ) {
      new FormattedTextFieldDemo().start();
   }
}

question_comments.body: @Holger see, we need an id for persisting. We don't persist plain strings. So there must be a key and a string representation in the field at a minimum. Unless we keep the two separate which would make for messy code (related attributes should be grouped together)

The user doesn’t see what instance of a Java class has been associated with a text field. The used wouldn’t even notice if you had an ordinary JTextField that always has a String rather than a custom object. But the user does notice when an operation suddenly has a lag due to the access of external resources. There is nothing wrong with presenting asynchronously fetched data inside the same component in a seamless way but that doesn’t mean that the component’s data model has to contain those data. The additional data affect the presentation but not the model (data the user has entered).

@Holger our users' expectations are different in that regard. However, keep in mind, the object may be a trimmed version of a DB entity, some simple DTO with an id and text representation as a bare minimum

A formatted textfield for an ID should contain that ID (can be a custom type instead of a String) but not a database record. The formatter should be responsible for checking whether the input has the right shape for a database ID but not fetch the database entry for that ID. When I enter an ISBN into a search field I do not expect the entire book being stored in that field. It’s only the trigger for the actual search.
@camickr JTextFields don't store non-string objects. It is important for me that the field contains values of domain types, not just plain strings

I want any conversion attempts to take place only once the string is submitted by the user — on Enter - As suggested by Abra, maybe just use a JTextField and add an ActionListener to the text field. The listener will automatically be invoked when Enter is pressed at which time you do your formatting.
Maybe JFormattedTextField is not the most appropriate component for your needs. Have you considered input verifier or document filter or FocusListener or ActionListener?
@JustanotherJavaprogrammer true, but it's not the topic of the question
You should the db lookup in another thread. Now it performs the db lookup in the swing event thread, which is wrong because it locks up the GUI. Look at SwingWorker for examples.

79803820.body: Read up on Other Swing Features, especially How to Use Actions and How to use Key Bindings. The idea is to create Actions that can be used in multiple ways. For example you can create an Action to be used by a JMenuIten a JButton and a KeyStroke. All Swing components use Key Bindings to bind an KeyStroke. Check out Key Bindings for a list of all the bindings for each component.

@camickr For example, if I have a single component and only need to respond to the “enter” key press event, I would use a Key because it avoids listening to “click” and other events that I am not interested in. On the other hand (which is more common), if I have many components and need to manage different types of events, I apply the same Action to all of them and determine the appropriate source and handling in their actionPerformed(). Am I correct?

@camickr I can't find any indication in the documentation that Action should be preferred over Key, but... in all the examples I have reviewed, they implement Action, so I deduce that the preference is based on “promoting centralized event handling,” and this is context-dependent.

Swing attempts to get away from handling low level mouse and key events. For example, to handle a click on a button you use an ActionListener, not a MouseListener. This is the same concept for a text field. Instead of listening for a KeyEvent you use an ActionListener. This method exists in the JTextField API specifically for this reason. The Swing tutorial on How to Use Text Fields has a simple example of using an ActionListener.
@camickr Sorry for the “silly” question, but why do you suggest using an ActionListener instead of a KeyListener, which would seem to be the logical choice?
Use an ActionListener, not a KeyListener. If you ever do need to use a KeyListener then don't use magic numbers like "10". Instead use KeyEvent.VK_ENTER.
@SergeyZolotarev I fixed the problem that was preventing it from compiling. If you enter text in the field and press “enter,” it will display something like: “Person xx.”
Your code is not compilable (I don't refer to imports) and doesn't change the field's value (field.getValue() will still return null)
@SergeyZolotarev I have edited it, now the field shows what the toString() of Person returns.
@SergeyZolotarev Do you need the same field that receives user input to display the Person object that has been created?
Your code does not set any values for the JFormattedField
